Description: Ostracon, large fragment of the body of a light-brown pottery vessel, the fabric is partly grey in section, the interior is covered with a brown resinous deposit, the exterior is slightly ribbed and covered with a light-brown slip with remains of two lines of Coptic text written in black ink, with faint traces of a further two lines of text, partly overwritten, containing an invoice.
Curator's comments: The character of this ostracon is not certain, owing to its brevity. It may conceivably be a receipt without a date; but it seems unlikely that receipts, except by an accident, would be issued without a date, and on the whole it is most probable that it was a note of the destination and, in most cases, nature and amount, of a consignment, sent with it as a check on full delivery.

As Mathias and Hor are both known as camel-drivers, it seems likely that they are the persons named in the inscription, the consignee not being mentioned; cf. too 1923,0327.477 (O.Sarga 201), where the camel-driver is named at the beginning. The ostracon is a palimpsest, traces (two lines) of an earlier text, written before this piece of pot was broken off, being visible at the top.
Bibliographic references: Crum & Bell 1922 / Wadi Sarga: Coptic and Greek texts (p.154)
Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (36340) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/36340)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: O.Sarga 200 (text edition abbreviation according to Oates et al 2001)
